content.description: Start sitting just inside the cave (a few feet left of the overhead hole) Start matched on the bigÂ left-facing jug flake. Climb right then up through the hole.
content.location: Climbs up through the hole between the 2 boulders. Starts just inside the cave between Shorty Pie and Small Guy.

content.description:
Start on Dem Bones, but traverse right into Better Than Coffee.

Sit start, left

hand on large sidepull, with right hand just under on an edge. Move up

and right to small edges, then a

big move into a right hand gaston.

Bump into the perfect cracks and go up.

A solid, fun v2 that is worth getting on (Just a step below Better Than Coffee and Dem Bones). Tweakers follows a right leaning crack like system, and tops out around 10-12 feet. You won't be writing home about it, but it's another fun thing to do when you do the Warm Up area.
content.location: Around the corner and to the right from Cave Club and Cave Man. Look for a right leaning, featured crack with smaller holds on the face itself.

content.description:
Cool body position and solid rock.

Start by stepping up onto the little slab, with your left hand on the arete, and then move your right hand into the jug gaston. Work your left hand up the arete, and go straight up.
content.location: Just left of the Plank on the little boulder left of Dem Bones and Sling Blade.

content.description: Stand start choosing from a variety of holds on the left edge of the boulder.  Toss up and right to the jug on Sling Blade.  Top out on jugs.
content.location: Starts left of Sling Blade, between the two boulders, and joins sling blade at the jug flake.

content.description: Start low on a good incut, then move to a couple of crimpers.  Do a big lockoff move to a gastoney jug.  Finish 'er up
content.location: On the warm up boulder, just left of Dem Bones

content.description:
Less obvious than the Plank, and avoids the best features of it, too.

Start standing with your right hand on the arete, and left hand on a face hold. Work your way up the face, keeping your right hand on the arete.
content.location: Just right of the Plank, using the right arete. It's on the little boulder left of Dem Bones and Sling Blade.

content.description: Climb into the obvious scoop on the west face.  Trend left following a sandy crack system and topout at 20+ feet.  Insecure and a little dirty.
content.protection: A crashpad will get you started but don't fall of the top of this one.

content.description: Another fun easy climb on the Warm Up boulder circuit. Start seated with a good jug, and work up right.
content.location: Look for this on the slight bulge around the corner to the right from the Cave Man and Cave Club cave. This is the first climb you come to. The next, on the undercut rail, is Bitter Bite.

content.description: Stand start on underling.  Left hand to sidepull jug.  Walk the plank by traversing up and right on slabby feet and snag the R arete and take it to the top.
content.location: Standing start on the huge undercling on the North side of warm-up, between Todd's Arete and Shorty Pie

content.description: Start standing on the small rock with a right hand side pull and left hand on a small crimp. Bump left to a little dish and set your feet on the smooth face for a lunge to a decent in-cut crimp. match hands and mantle up to better holds. It's a fun short problem and the landing is perfect. Caldiero guide gives it V4, might be a little soft but that's Joes for you.
content.location: This is to the left of Todd's Arete. If you are facing tweakers, it is on the right boulder. Start standing on the little rock and lean left to reach the starting left hand hold.

content.description: Start standing with small pockets and a good ledge for your foot.  Slap right into the seam then make a long move to a small crimp.  A few more tenuous moves gets you to easier ground but keep it together for the tall, sandy topout.  A great boulder problem and would be classic if a bit cleaner up top.
content.protection: Crashpads and a spotter is a good idea.
content.location: Just left of the obvious arete (#2 Arete) seen when approaching the boulder from the road.

content.description: A not terribly noteworthy, but still worthwhile, v1 on the little extra boulder attached to the main Warm Up boulder.
content.location: Isaac's guide provides a nice photo for finding this, but I'll do my best. Once you've found the main Warm Up boulder, walk around to the left, past Dem Bones and Sling Blade. You'll find another sizable (maybe 12-15') and separate boulder. Eye Patch is on the backside of this, up the face without any very large holds. To the left of it is a crappy v4, and to the right, just around the corner lay two nice climbs using a big flakey thing and starting on a ramp.

content.description: Follow a left and upward angling large horizontal crack to the ledge which is immediately to the right and above the distinct feature in 3 weeks. From the ledge continue up the second slab using the leftward trending flake undercling before topping out.
content.protection: Bouldering pads. You may elect to have a spotter toss one to the first ledge. Otherwise the route is pretty tall for the grade.
content.location: The start is on the slab around the corner right of 3 weeks. Start at the tree base (might be helpful to have your spotter hold the tree back on the first few moves).

content.description: This is the problem in the cave on the split boulder. Start as far left as possible on jugs and traverse right with a gaston move to the right side of the crack. Match, then layback the corner with rad foot cams to the apex of the split and pull over. The wall behind makes the topout kinda squeezy and awkward.
content.protection: A couple pads and careful spotting, the topout of the problem is kinda dangerous and a boulder sits beneath the crux.
content.location: In the "cave" on the big boulder.

content.description:
Rather than starting on the left side, and traversing out, a la Cave Man, start sitting with the undercling, and climb straight up. Don't use the left side of the crack for this one (ELIMINATE). Normally, I loathe eliminates (for many reasons that I don't have time to get into here), but this boulder is fun enough that it's actually worth it. Shocking. It flows well, and climbs differently than if you use the left side of the crack.

Watch yourself on the potential back dab while you're topping it out.
content.location: In the little cave on the right side of the formation as you walk up from the turn-out. Cave Man starts deep and traverses, using everything. Cave Club starts under the right face, and avoids the rock to the left of the big crack.

content.description: On the right side of the north face start sitting on good holds. Make a move or two to a SHARP left and go up on huge incut jugs.
content.location: around the corner to the left of Better Than Coffee

content.description: From a sit, follow the rail up and right. Good holds and low commitment.
content.location: Around the corner to the right from Cave Club and Cave Man, look for the undercut rail and the bleached fin.

content.description: Sit start on Scoopable, stay low and traverse up and left into Better than Coffee.
content.protection: A few pads, you climb over the tree and will want to pad it up

content.description: Make a couple of slightly awkward moves to get established above the overhang, then lay into the crack cleaving the face. Top out easily, high off the ground. Utah Bouldering calls it V4, R&I mini guide calls it V1... you decide!
content.protection: A couple pads and a spotter.
content.location: On the side of the big boulder that faces the road, climbs the left side of the face via the prominent crack.

content.description: The Afterthought is one of the best V9âs in Joes Valley. The bullet rock, perfect sidepulls, and uncontrived movement are what makes it so good. Start squatting with the right hand on an okay sidepull and the left on a sloper sidepull opposing the right hand. Pull on with difficulty and make a hard bump with the left to a pretty good sloper sidepull. Adjust the feet and lunge to a good sloper at the lip. Top out on crimps. On first sight, this looks like a very doable V9, but pull of the ground and you will quickly find out why it never gets done. Nonetheless, the Afterthought is a classic rock climb and should not be missed.
content.protection: Three or four pads. The problem is not far off of the ground but the dyno is uncontrolled.
content.location: The leftmost route on the Slasher boulder. Up the hill from the warm-up boulders. It is a big square looking boulder.

content.description:
Start with both hands matched on the obvious smiley face crimp. Find a foot that works for you. Pull off the ground and pop to a hidden incut crimp.

Mantel into the scoop using some finesse or power. Or a bit of both.

Once established in the scoop, finish up the easy slab.

Finger size will play a large role in how difficult this feels. With my fat fingers, it felt solid at v8.
content.protection: As there is a rock protruding from the base of the climb, a few pads are ideal to flatten out the landing. Though the boulder behind you is intimidating during the mantel, I've never seen anyone actually hit it and falls generally go away from it.
content.location: This problem is one of the first climbs you see when walking up from the parking. It is located just to the left of where the two boulders touch.

content.description: Grab high slopers and mantel/grovel into the beautiful scoop with nasty slopers and a slippery heel hook, snagging the flake before the foot blows and sends you flying. Insecure, spooky and rad. Starting from the sharp crimps below the scoop is V9.
content.protection: A pad and spotters to keep you from splitting your skull on the boulder behind.
content.location: Just outside the "cave" on the large boulder is a high scoop. Mantel it.
